sols_html:
We will use the ratio test to prove that this series is absolutely convergent. Each term in the series is

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = \frac{(-2011)^n}{n!}\end{aligned}\]

and so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n} = \frac{\frac{(-2011)^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}}{ \frac{(-2011)^n}{n!}} = \frac{-2011 n!}{(n+1)!} = -\frac{2011}{n+1}\end{aligned}\]

We see then that \(\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n} = 0 < 1\), and so the series converges absolutely.

As per the second hint, we note that the series is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-2011)^n}{n!} = e^{-2011}\end{aligned}\]

Since the function \(e^x\) converges absolutely over the whole real line, it follows that this series does as well.
